natural problem: If $a\equiv 18\pmod{42}$ and $b\equiv 73\pmod{42}$, then for what integer $n$ in the set $\{100,101,102,\ldots,140,141\}$ is it true that $$a-b\equiv n\pmod{42}~?$$
natural solution: Reading all congruences $\pmod{42}$, we have \begin{align} a-b &\equiv 18-73 \\ &\equiv -55 \\ &\equiv -55+42+42 \\ &\equiv 29\pmod{42}. \end{align}That's great, except we want to find $n$ with $100\leq n<142$.

Therefore we should add copies of 42 until we get into this range: \[29\equiv 29+42\equiv71\pmod{42}.\]That's not large enough. \[71\equiv71+42\equiv113\pmod{42}.\]That is in our range, so $n=\boxed{113}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b n :: int
assumes h0 : "[a = 18] (mod 42)"
and h1 : "[b = 73] (mod 42)"
shows  "\<exists> n. n \<in> {100..141} \<and> [a - b = n] (mod 42)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 ### Proof
 Reading all congruences $\pmod{42}$, we have \begin{align} a-b &\equiv 18-73 \\ &\equiv -55 \\ &\equiv -55+42+42 \\ &\equiv 29\pmod{42}. \end{align}That's great, except we want to find $n$ with $100\leq n<142$.
 Therefore we should add copies of 42 until we get into this range: \[29\equiv 29+42\equiv71\pmod{42}.\]That's not large enough. \[71\equiv71+42\equiv113\pmod{42}.\]That is in our range, so $n=\boxed{113}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b n :: int
assumes h0 : "[a = 18] (mod 42)"
and h1 : "[b = 73] (mod 42)"
shows  "\<exists> n. n \<in> {100..141} \<and> [a - b = n] (mod 42)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given that $a$ is congruent to $18$ modulo $42$ and $b$ is congruent to $73$ modulo $42$, find an integer $n$ between $100$ and $141$ inclusive such that $a - b$ is congruent to $n$ modulo $42$.
